column2: 我々の世界は宇宙のほんの小さな一部分に過ぎない。

column1: Out of sight out of mind. When you're separated you lose touch.
column2: 去る者は日々に疎しだな。お互いに離ればなれになると、自然と疎遠になるよね。

column1: Out of sight, out of mind.

column1: Out of sight, out of mind.
column2: 目にふれなくなると、忘れ去られてしまう。

column1: Out of sight, out of mind.
column2: 目に見えないものは忘れさられる。

column1: Out of sight, out of mind.
column2: 目に見えないものは忘れられる。

column1: Out of sight, out of mind.
column2: 身近にいないと忘れ去られる。

column1: Out of the mouth comes evil.
column2: 口は災いの元。

column1: Out rushed the man and his wife.
column2: その男と妻は飛び出して行った。

column1: Pack eggs in dozens.
column2: 卵を一ダースづつつめなさい。

column1: Pains of love be sweeter far / Than all other pleasures are.
column2: 恋の苦悩は他のあらゆる喜びよりも遥かに甘美である。

column1: Parents are always worried about the future of their children.
column2: 親はいつも子供の将来のことを心配している。

column1: Parents are proud of their children when they do well in school.
column2: 親は学校の成績が良ければ子供を誇りに思う。

column1: Parents do tend to take their children to the doctor quickly.
column2: 親はすぐにこどもを病院に連れてくる

column1: Parents may favor the youngest child in the family.
column2: 両親は、末っ子をえこひいきするかもしれない。

column1: Paris has a great charm for Japanese girls.
column2: パリは日本の女性にとってとても魅力のあるところだ。

column1: Parliament is now in session.
column2: 国会は今会期中である。

column1: Part of the charm of a big city lies in the variety of styles that can be seen in the architecture of its buildings.
column2: 大都市の魅力のひとつは、その建物の建築様式に見られる多様性にある。

column1: Parts of the country are so dry as to be almost desert.
column2: その国の所々はあまりにも乾燥しており、ほとんど砂漠みたいだ。

column1: Pass me the pen.

column1: Pass the sugar, please.

column1: Pass the sugar, please.

column1: Passengers for Cambridge, please make your way to platform No.6.
column2: ケンブリッジに向かうお客様、６番ホームへお進みください。

column2: 乗客たちは道路にどっと降りた。

column1: Passing through the strong wind, the planes rock like this, but don't worry.
column2: 強風の間を通り抜けるときに、飛行機はこんなふうに揺れるんだけど、心配しなくていいよ。

column1: Pat's going to Jim's birthday party.
column2: パットはジムの誕生日パーティーに行く予定です。

column1: Patients often die simply because they yield to their diseases.
column2: 患者はただ自らの病気に屈して死ぬことがよくある。

column1: Patricia will organize the tournament.
column2: パトリシアがそのトーナメントを組むでしょう。

column1: Patting me on the shoulder, he thanked me for helping him.
column2: 私の肩を軽く叩いて彼は私の助力に感謝した。

column1: Paul is by far the most charming boy in our school.
column2: ポールは学校で飛び抜けて魅力のある生徒だ。

column1: Paul makes it a rule not to be late for his appointments.
column2: ポールは約束の時間に遅れないようにしている。

column1: Paul prefers English to math.
column2: ポールは数学より英語が好きです。

column1: Paula is going to wash the car tomorrow.

column1: Peggy did not go to see the drama, and neither did I.

column1: People are crying out against the new tax.

column1: People are given a lot of pleasure by music.

column1: People commit a crime.

column1: People could have avoided many mistakes by simple experiments.
column2: 簡単な実験をすれば、多くの誤りが避けられたであろう。

column1: People feel most at ease when they are at home.

column1: People have many things to communicate and many ways to do so.

column1: People have more leisure than they have ever had.
column2: 人々はかつてないほどの余暇を持っている。

column1: People in Brazil were proud of him.
column2: ブラジルの人々は彼を誇りに思いました。

column1: People in towns are attracted by life in the country.

column1: People laughed at him.
column2: 人々は彼を嘲笑った。

column1: People laughed at the boy.

column1: People liked him all the better for his faults.

column1: People living in a big city tend to lack exercise.
column2: 大都会に住んでいる人は運動不足になりがちだ。

column1: People living in town don't know the pleasures of country life.

column1: People no longer consider it strange for men to let their hair grow long.

column1: People of 65 and above get a pension from the government.

column1: People of this country do not respect their old traditions any longer.

column1: People often don't notice their own faults.

column1: People seek escape from the heat of the town.

column1: People struggled against poverty.
column2: 人々は貧困に向かって奮闘した。

column1: People tomorrow will have different ideas.

column1: People used to laugh at him behind his back.
column2: 人々は陰で彼を嘲笑したものだった。

column1: People want more money to expand educational institutions.

column1: People who make no noise are dangerous.

column1: Perform an act of charity.

column1: Persons with special skills can easily get jobs.

column1: Philosophy is not so difficult a subject as you imagine it is.
column2: 哲学はあなたがたが考えているほど難しい学科ではない。

column2: 君のチームには決勝戦で勝つチャンスはないよ。

column1: Your tie blends well with your suit.
column2: 君のネクタイは背広によく調和している。

column1: Your watch is more expensive than mine.
column2: 君の時計の方が私の時計より値段が高い。

column1: Your watch is superior in quality to mine.
column2: あなたの時計は私のより質の点で優れている。

column1: Your watch seems to be very valuable.
column2: 君の時計は高いそうですね。

column1: Your wife is mad at you.
column2: 奥さんがカンカンだぞ。

column1: Your writing is good except for a few mistakes.
column2: いくつかの誤りを除いてほかは、あなたの文章はすばらしい。

column1: Yours is a very strange story.
column2: あなたのは初めて耳にする妙なお話です。

column1: Yumi will use this camera tomorrow afternoon.
column2: 由美は明日の午後このカメラを使うでしょう。

column1: Yumiko belongs to the tennis club.
column2: ユミコはテニス部に所属しています。
